price_objections.objection: Your price is higher than [handyman/general contractor/other bid]
price_objections.handler: I understand you're comparing options. The difference you're seeing reflects specialized finish carpentry skills versus general carpentry. Finish work requires precision measuring, compound miter cuts, understanding of wood movement, and an eye for detail that takes years to develop. The lower bid might mean visible nail holes, gaps that appear as wood settles, or joints that don't align. I'm pricing for work that you'll be proud of for decades, not just work that's 'done.' Can I show you photos of jobs where we fixed another contractor's finish work so you can see the difference?
price_objections.reframe: Think of it as the difference between a tailor and someone who can sew. Both can attach fabric, but only one creates a garment you'd wear proudly. What's your priority—lowest price or best result?

diy_objection.objection: I'm thinking about just doing this myself
diy_objection.handler: I respect that, and some homeowners have the skills and tools to do their own finish work. Before you decide, consider that finish carpentry requires a compound miter saw, coping saw, nail gun, and experience with measuring, cutting complex angles, and scribing to uneven walls. Most DIYers find that materials cost more than expected because of mistakes, and it takes 3-4 times longer than anticipated. The biggest risk is ending up with something that looks 'homemade' rather than professional, which actually decreases your home value. What if we did the most visible areas like the main living spaces, and you could tackle the closets or basement yourself?
diy_objection.reframe: How many weekends are you willing to invest, and what would it mean if the results weren't what you hoped after all that time?

timing_objection.objection: We're not ready to start yet / We want to wait until [later time]
timing_objection.handler: I completely understand wanting to time this right. Can I ask what needs to happen before you'd be ready? [Listen] The reality is that skilled finish carpenters stay booked 4-8 weeks out during busy seasons. If you wait until you feel completely ready, you might be waiting another 2-3 months beyond that for an opening. Also, finish work is often what makes a space feel complete—many clients tell me they wish they'd done it sooner because they were living with the frustration longer than necessary. What if we scheduled for [appropriate timeframe] so you're on the calendar, with the understanding you can adjust if needed?
timing_objection.reframe: What's the cost of waiting—not just in dollars, but in continuing to live with spaces that bother you every day?

scope_uncertainty.objection: I'm not sure exactly what we need / We might want to do more later
scope_uncertainty.handler: That's actually very common, and I'd rather help you think it through now than have you regret not doing it all at once. Here's why: matching stain or paint months later is difficult, I'm already set up with tools and materials, and you've already disrupted your home. It's almost always more cost-effective to do it together. What I suggest is we walk through your space together, I'll point out what would make the biggest impact, and we can create a priority list. Then you can decide what fits your budget now versus later. Would that be helpful?
scope_uncertainty.reframe: Let's identify your must-haves versus nice-to-haves, so you make decisions you'll feel good about long-term.

trust_objection.objection: We've been burned by contractors before
trust_objection.handler: I hear that a lot, and I'm sorry you had that experience. It's exactly why I focus on finish carpentry exclusively—I'm not juggling multiple trades or spreading myself thin. Here's how I work differently: [specific process like detailed contract, progress photos, scheduled check-ins, written timeline]. I also provide references from recent clients you can actually call, and I can show you photos of jobs in progress, not just finished glamour shots. What specifically went wrong before, so I can address how I handle that differently?
trust_objection.reframe: Trust is earned through transparency and follow-through. What would you need to see or hear to feel confident moving forward?

material_confusion.objection: I don't know what type of trim/wood/style we should use
material_confusion.handler: That's exactly the kind of guidance I provide—it's part of the service. The right choice depends on your home's style, your budget, and how you use the space. For example, MDF is cost-effective and paints beautifully for painted trim, while solid wood is better for stained work or high-impact areas. I bring samples, show you options in your price range, and explain the pros and cons of each. Most clients find this consultation alone is worth it because they make confident decisions instead of second-guessing. Would it help if I came out to assess your space and show you appropriate options?
material_confusion.reframe: You don't need to be the expert—that's what you're hiring me for. My job is to guide you to choices you'll love that fit your budget.

educational.title: Why Your Baseboards Have Gaps (And How We Fix It)
educational.hook: See this gap? It's not the installer's fault—it's your walls.
educational.body: Most walls aren't perfectly straight. We use a technique called scribing—tracing the wall's contour onto the baseboard, then cutting a custom fit. We also cope inside corners instead of mitering them. When the house settles, coped joints stay tight while miters open up. That's the difference between trim that lasts 2 years and trim that lasts 20.

educational.title: The Crown Molding Math Nobody Tells You
educational.hook: Crown molding isn't expensive because of materials—it's the geometry.
educational.body: Every crown molding cut is a compound miter. That means two angles at once: the miter angle AND the bevel angle. Get either wrong by half a degree, and your joint has a visible gap. In a room with 8 corners, that's 16 perfect cuts. We use digital angle finders and make test cuts because your ceiling height, wall angles, and crown size all change the math.

educational.title: Cabinet Filler Strips: The Secret to Custom Looks
educational.hook: This $30 piece of wood makes $5,000 cabinets look custom.
educational.body: Stock cabinets come in 3-inch increments. Your wall? Probably not a perfect multiple of 3. Filler strips fill those gaps and let us scribe cabinets perfectly to walls. We match the grain direction, stain them identically, and install them so they're invisible. It's the difference between 'builder grade' and 'wow, those look expensive.'

Don't get me wrong - PL Premium has its place. But it's not a substitute for understanding wood movement.
I'm seeing DIYers glue hardwood directly to drywall. No expansion gaps. No floating panels. Just glue.
Then they call ME when it cracks 6 months later. And somehow I'm the bad guy for not fixing it cheap.
Real finish carpentry accounts for: Humidity, wood species, grain direction, seasonal movement, structural load.
A bead of glue accounts for: Nothing. It just holds until it doesn't.
We should be teaching fundamentals: Proper nailing patterns, scribe techniques, understanding materials.
Instead we're creating a generation that thinks every problem is solved with caulk and glue.
End rant. But seriously - if you're learning online, find creators who explain the WHY, not just the quick fix.

thread_structure: 7 things I check before starting ANY finish carpentry job. #4 has saved me from disaster more times than I can count: 🧵
1. Moisture content of existing framing. If it's over 12%, we're not installing trim until it dries. Period.
2. Wall plumb and ceiling level. I don't care what GC says is "close enough." I document everything with photos.
3. HVAC/electrical rough-in photos. You'd be shocked how often someone drills through my work later.
4. Paint schedule. Who's painting what, when, and with what products. This prevents 90% of finger-pointing.
5. Material acclimation time. Hardwood needs 72 hours minimum in the space. No exceptions.
6. Access and protection plan. How am I getting materials in? What am I protecting? Who pays for damage?
7. Payment schedule tied to milestones, not calendar dates. Keeps everyone honest and on track.
Miss any of these and you're asking for problems. What's on your pre-job checklist? 👇

Year 3-5: Started doing my own trim on weekends. Charged barely above material cost. Built portfolio.
Year 5-7: Took a PAY CUT to work for a high-end finish carpenter. Best decision I ever made.

Year 7-10: Went out on my own. Started at $35/hour. Raised rates $5 every 6 months as demand grew.
Year 10-12: Niched down to custom built-ins and architectural millwork. Stopped doing basic trim.
Year 12-15: Built reputation through word-of-mouth and (honestly) Instagram. Stopped advertising.
Today: Booked 4 months out, choose my projects, make 7x what I made framing. Same hours, way less pain.
The key: Never stopped learning. Every job taught me something. Still watch YouTube tutorials weekly.
You don't need to follow my path. But you DO need a plan. What's yours? 👇
